definitions: A configuration setting in web development, specifically for servers, that specifies a list of origins (domains, protocols, and ports) that are permitted to make cross-origin requests to the server. This is a security feature to prevent unauthorized access to resources from different domains.
examples: Set CORS_ALLOWED_ORIGINS to allow frontend access.
Misconfiguring CORS_ALLOWED_ORIGINS can lead to security vulnerabilities.
The server rejected the request due to an invalid CORS_ALLOWED_ORIGINS setting.
